comments.commentBody:
Across Lite filled in the blanks on my grid! Is that some kind of sign or am I being dotty?
My favorite hidden sign is bigeminies.

I've found that avoiding caffiene after 4 p.m. helps a lot. The problem isn't so much falling asleep or waking up at night, these things happen normally. It's when I awaken at night. If I have caffiene in my system then my heart "wakes up" and that makes falling back to sleep a challenge. Without caffiene, I can wake up, shuffle around, read the New York Times online, post a comment, and go back to sleep wihout difficulty. Maybe sleep-commenting is a new form of sleep walking.

I am a 60 year old woman with hotflashes several times a day and night.  I tend to be able to fall asleep but wake 4 to 5 hours later burning up, no matter how cool I keep the room and how light the covers or clothing.  Once awake it takes a while to cool down. Once cooled, if I try to fall asleep again I often have another hot flash.  Many nights I never fall back to sleep and lie awake til morning, or give up after a couple of hours and get up early and read or exercise or work.  I have tried all the herbal remedies for hot flashes, avoid chocolate and spice foods and red wine, do not drink caffeine.  I am not willing to take replacement hormones.  I would appreciate suggestions.

I'm a young academic and I've had sleep problems for a very long time now - trouble falling asleep, staying asleep, going back to sleep when woken, feeling tired and not properly rested when waking, and needing earplugs and eye mask every night. Everyone in my field has told me they share the same problems. Most just stay awake nearly the whole night. They claim to get their work done that way, but for me it is too taxing to continue this way. Daily exercise doesn't seem to help much. I've tried medication, but it all makes me extremely nauseous and gives me bad dreams. Is there something natural one can do to avoid what seems like work-spurred destiny?

Like many of the earlier comments, I find that I can usually fall asleep, but then wake up after 3 to 5 hours of sleep to use the bathroom (I'm a 52 yo male) and then often have trouble falling asleep again. I've used melatonin with some success, and find that it helps if I avoid a large evening time meal.

I also have an occasional problem where a pop song or jingle I hear on the radio or TV during the day will start playing in my head when I awake during the night, and I can't get it to stop. It was so bad 10 years ago that I switched to all classical, but even then familiar tunes (e.g., Beethoven's Fifth) will sometimes cue up and play.

I'd be interested to hear what other tips are recommended by the experts.

Art

I developed sleep maintenance insomnia when I was in my late 30s, working at a very stressful job for more than 7 years. I had slept normally until then.

I went to a sleep specialist, was prescribed the drug du jour, and have been on meds for 25+ years, another sleep specialist and now a psychiatrist. I have tried light boxes (made me sleepy at 9PM), sleep diaries, yellow glasses for blue light. I probably have a circadian rhythm disorder - I would stay up until all hours if I didn't make myself go to bed at midnight.

Since I don't watch TV, I find that watching videos keeps me up, so I avoid them.

I now take 20mg Restoril, 200mg Neurontin, an antihistamine (I switch them) and .5MG melatonin to sleep. I wear an eye mask to stimulate melatonin production and avoid having morning light awaken me too early. I do all of this in careful consultation with a bio-psychiatrist who I see solely for my sleep.

I am extremely healthy, normal weight, etc. No one has ever been able to find an underlying disorder. A couple of nights a month, the drugs fail and I'm miserable.

I don't even want to think what all these meds have done to my body - they've certainly destroyed my ability to fall asleep without drugs. At the same time, I've had easily 25 healthy, productive years.

I have heard that monkeying around with body temperature helps - cold feet, cold room - but we're all one large, uncontrolled experiment - and not just because of the sleep meds - all the meds, taken in combination, for decades.

I read "don't take Ambien for more than 7 days" and laugh.

In the winter, I sleep very well, but in the summer, I'm plagued with insomnia.  I've tried cooling down my room and dark curtains to keep the light out, but I'm still wide awake even when I'm utterly exhausted.  What else can I do to actually fall asleep?

I have a similiar problem as several other post per no problem falling asleep but wake up in 2-4 hours, usually around 3:00 and have trouble getting back to sleep. If do get back to sleep it's usually around 5-6:00 and only for another hour or so. Does not matter if physically active all day.Am 51 and have had this problem for many years.Not overweight, videotaped myself, did not hear snoring or anything unusual. Cannot remember the last time I slept fot 6 hours srtaight. Concluded it's nervous system, age related? Doubt it would be sleep apnea per would think I would fall back asleep. Thanks

I can never fall asleep naturally. I've been taking Unisom every night for the last 15 years. I'm up to 2 tablets to get to sleep (sometimes I have to add Valerian also). I wake up a few hours later, get up, take two more Unisom and can get back to sleep after 20-60 minutes. I'm worried about taking an antihistamine for so long, I've developed food allergies and wonder if there is a connection?

Afghanistan is a failed state; we can spend billions and never get it to come together. We need to get out of it now. That was Bush's folly, and now it is slowly becoming Obama's folly. It's a case of spending good money after bad and all to a faint purpose. To try what succeeded in Iraq is not the answer. Tribal loyalties prevail and the Taliban do what we would never do--kill those who will help their own country and the Americans, and not side with them.  We do not need another Vietnam.

On Wednesday we will find out if our president is really smart.  If he already has a good replacement for McCrystal he should accept his resignation and move on.  If not,president Obama should accept his apology and then direct McCrystal to return to Afghanistan and finish the job.  McCrystal must be able to save face if he is to be a functional leader.  In addition, McCrystal must man up in front of his troops or they will lose all respect for him.  If McCrystal is smart he should realize that three strikes and you are out.  I don't think he will make that third mistake.
The only rational Afghan policy is to get out of there now.

General McChrystal being the man on the spot may have a different perception, reading of the situation and a counter-insurgency strategy to grpple with the situation in Kabul. His team members too may have different views in tackling the situation. The White House mandate must be very clear to them and as is reported there is no policy disagreement between President Obama and General McChrystal. General McChrystal is reputed to be fiercely self-disciplined. His reported comments including derisive quotes of aides in the Rolling Stone mag only slight and belittle his stature and reputation. He could be more restrained in voicing his and aides' views, despite under tremendous pressure. Difference of views apart such restraint would only enhance his image and help the President in finding a more workable and better solution tothe problem.

Give me a break.

Every bunch of leaders have a little bit of ego.

We have to stop acting like silly geese when there are so many serious problems that we need to spend time on.

There are three serious wealth builders in Afghanistan which have become indigenous. These are the Narco business, support of the miltary tourism industry, and the normal corruption that exists in every country without good W-2s and viable tax collection system.

So the question is how long will it take to unwind these and bring about social and economic conversions so we can leave?

Why does'nt everyone begin acting like an adult.

The general must go. The Uniform Code of Military Justice provides that the President is the general`s superior officer.  The President is part of the chain of command.  If an inferior disrespects his superior, discipline is required.

General McChrystal violated the Uniform Code of Military Justice and should be court martialed or fired for insubordination.  If the President lets him off the hook, this will open the door for any military officer, non-commissioned officer or soldier to ignore the chain of command and the UCMJ.  If a four star can get away with blatant insubordination then it should be available to every military man regardless of rank.  The real question is where is the Chairman of the  JCS on this?  The chain of command in the military services appears to be seriously flawed.  I served as an Air Force officer during the Vietnam war.  In those days, McChrystal would already be a civilian.

This should be a no-brainer.  McChrystal was warned after shooting his mouth off in public in England.  He previously got a pass for his role in the Pat Tillman coverup (something the major media either never noticed or has quickly forgotten).  So it's not about second chances.  But beyond McChrystal, this is the time for Obama to reconsider fighting an unwinnable war on behalf of a corrupt, disloyal and unreliable "ally."

Gen.McChrystal is right, Obama has turned out to be a major dud. NYT should stop writing editorials like this asking the head of General and also look at otherside of the story on why Gen.McChrystal made those comments.

Come to think of it, media has their fingers all over these comments. Since when is the free press and bad press a good thing every time. The General's subordinates comments are not necessarily a reflection of his conscience....suggestive reasoning at best. This man has more time at war than any general in American history at this point and less blood on his hands than any other war time general I can think of either.

I hope somebody reads this!
Way to go out on a limb, there.

I think that Obama should've spent more time getting to know McChrystal and less time dithering on whether to send more troops like the General requested.  I also think that it probably rubbed some people the wrong way that Obama announced his decision (at a photo op at West Point) 6 months after the General's request and short changed him on what he said he needed to get the job done. I happen to agree with everything McChrystal said and I think he doesn't respect any of the so called " foreign policy/war experts" in the administration.

The reported indiscretions and unprofessionalism are astonishing, but there is a job to do. If the officer still has the POTUS' confidence, the troops he was given and the plan he was given need executing; the mission and the troops are more important than his 'acting out' or his staff's un-guarded comments to a reported who happened to become embedded for 2 months instead of conducing a 48-hour profile piece.

By the time the officer has gotten to the situation room, Gates and McMullen will have quite a bit of his hide, and I suspect the POTUS, and VP will be able to quickely dis-abuse him of any notion he may have that they are ' un-prepared '.

The general has many more months of work in Afghanistan with his team and a mission to complete for their commander-in-chief before any of them should get to begin new careers as consultants for military contractors.

btw - the General and each person mentioned in the Rolling Stone article, along with his whole HG staff, should each be presented with a signed portrait of the POTUS which they should be under orders to keep on their desks or on the HQ wall and salute every morning by each staff member without fail - under orders :)

Folks....the issue around the General is just a sideshow.  The real problem - which history has taught us over and over again - is that two fold - one, there is no such thing as a "war' in Afghanistan; and two, there is no such thing as a "victory" in Afghanistan.  Look, the Russians spent ten years throwing everything they had against the rebels in that country and they went home with no victory and just licking your wounds.  The U.S. is bound and determined to do the same thing.  Why?

McChrystal has lost his credibility entirely. President Obama must follow the course Truman set in firing MacArthur, another general who openly disagreed with his Commander-in-Chief.

Then, Obama must follow through on the promises made during his campaign and remove all US troops from Afghanistan in 2011. If it costs him the election - so be it - history will show it was the right thing to do.

Really, the President calls General McCrystal back from the field because of unflattering comments spoken in the Generals presence? Is the President THAT sensitive? And, let's face it. Vice President Biden has been known to be a little unclear during extemporaneous speaking.

President Obama certainly has the experience and expertise to spin a story. Now might be the time to consider a statement that could mediate any fallout for all party's involved. Perhaps over a friendly beer?
